subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
Oracle bone: {{liushu|p|nocap=1}}: 3 dots + {{l|zh|𠀠}} + {{l|zh|廾}} + optional {{l|zh|帚}}.

Small seal: {{Han compound|釆|𠦒|廾|ls=p|nocap=1}}.

The current glyph is from the small seal script.

subSections.title: Compounds
subSections.text:
{{zh-der|化糞池|佛頭著糞|底糞|朽木糞土|扒糞的|擔糞|拾糞人|視如糞土|朽木糞牆|糞筐|糞土|糞汁|糞壤窟室|糞棋|糞便|馬糞|糞窖子|糞夫|糞坑|著糞佛頭|葉落糞本|糞門|糞球|糞箕子|鳥糞層|糞除|血糞|驢糞毬|蠅糞點玉|馬糞紙|糞肥|賤如糞土|糞壤|背槽拋糞|糞箕}}

{{zh-cat|Intermediate}}

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|くそ}}
From {{inh|ja|jpx-pro|*kuso}}. Cognate with {{m|ja|臭い|tr=kusai||stinky, smelly}}, {{m|ja|腐る|tr=kusaru||to rot, to become stinky}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

subSections.title: Derived terms
Idioms
Usage notes
subSections.text: This is not considered as profane as the English glosses. For instance, a child of five using the Japanese interjection ''kuso'' would be unremarkable, whereas it would be very socially inappropriate for a child of five to use the English interjection {{m|en|shit}}.

subSections.title: Prefix
Suffix
Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text:
* This noun specifically refers to the excrement of non-human animals; for human excrement, the term {{m|ja|大便|tr=daiben}} is used.
* {{U:ja:comkanji|フン|糞}}

subSections.title: Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ばば}}
Appears to derive from [[baby talk]].<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> Compare {{cog|en|poopoo}}.
